briefdescription.para: Agents in this simulation.
Inverse desired simulation fps.
Use Double Buffering.
Use Interpolation.
KDTree for this simulation.
Obstacles in this simulation.
Worker threads.
Time in seconds between each simulation step.

detaileddescription.para: This is the desired delta time, the simulation will never run at a higher fps than the rate at which the Update function is called.

briefdescription.para: Use Interpolation.

detaileddescription.para: If interpolation is enabled, agent positions will be interpolated on frames when no rvo calculation is done. This has a very small overhead, but usually yields much smoother looking movement.

briefdescription.para: KDTree for this simulation.

detaileddescription.para: Used internally by the simulation. Please only read from this tree, do not rebuild it since that can interfere with the simulation. It is rebuilt when needed.

briefdescription.para: Is using multithreading.
Create a new simulator.

parameterdescription.para: Use the specified number of worker threads. When the number zero is specified, no multithreading will be used. A good number is the number of cores on the machine.

Use Double Buffering for calculations. Testing done with 5000 agents and 0.1 desired delta time showed that with double buffering enabled the game ran at 50 fps for most frames, dropping to 10 fps during calculation frames. But without double buffering it ran at around 10 fps all the time. This will let threads calculate while the game progresses instead of waiting for the calculations to finish.

simplesect.para: Will only have effect if using multithreading

briefdescription.para: Add a previously removed agent to the simulation.

detaileddescription.para: An agent can only be in one simulation at a time, any attempt to add an agent to two simulations or multiple times to the same simulation will result in an exception being thrown.

briefdescription.para: Add an agent at the specified position.

detaileddescription.para: You can use the returned interface to read several parameters such as position and velocity and set for example radius and desired velocity.

briefdescription.para: Adds a previously removed obstacle.

detaileddescription.para: This does not check if the obstacle is already added to the simulation, so please do not add an obstacle multiple times.
It is assumed that this is a valid obstacle.

briefdescription.para: Adds an obstacle described by the vertices.
Adds an obstacle described by the vertices.
Adds a line obstacle with a specified height.
Removes all agents from the simulation.
Get a list of all agents.

detaileddescription.para: This is an internal list. I'm not going to be restrictive so you may access it since it is better for performance but please do not modify it since that can cause errors in the simulation.

briefdescription.para: Get a list of all obstacles.

detaileddescription.para: This is a list of obstacle vertices. Each vertex is part of a doubly linked list loop forming an obstacle polygon.

briefdescription.para: Removes a specified agent from this simulation.

detaileddescription.para: The agent can be added again later by using AddAgent.

briefdescription.para: Removes the obstacle identified by the vertex.

detaileddescription.para: This must be the same vertex as the one returned by the AddObstacle call.

briefdescription.para: Should be called once per frame.
Updates the vertices of an obstacle.

detaileddescription.para:
obstacle
Obstacle to update
vertices
New vertices for the obstacle, must have at least the number of vertices in the original obstacle
matrix
Matrix to multiply vertices with before updating obstacle
The number of vertices in an obstacle cannot be changed, existing vertices can only be moved.

briefdescription.para: Rebuilds the obstacle tree at next simulation frame.

detaileddescription.para: Add and remove obstacle functions call this automatically.

briefdescription.para: Terminates any worker threads.
Local Avoidance Simulator.

detaileddescription.para: This class handles local avoidance simulation for a number of agents using Reciprocal Velocity Obstacles (RVO) and Optimal Reciprocal Collision Avoidance (ORCA).

This class will handle calculation of velocities from desired velocities supplied by a script. It is, however, not responsible for moving any objects in a Unity Scene. For that there are other scripts (see below).

Obstacles can be added and removed from the simulation, agents can also be added and removed at any time.
RVOSimulator RVOAgent Pathfinding.RVO.IAgent The implementation is based on the RVO2 Library (http://gamma.cs.unc.edu/RVO2/) extended with many new features.
